 PD: That was filmed inside our airplane, and so, you can now do this.,We're based down in Florida.,Let me talk about the other thing I'm excited about.,The future of prizes. You know, prizes are a very old idea.,I had the pleasure of borrowing from the Longitude Prize,and the Orteig Prize that put Lindbergh forward.,And we have made a decision in the X PRIZE Foundation,to actually carry that concept forward into other technology areas,,and we just took on a new mission statement:,"to bring about radical breakthroughs in space,and other technologies for the benefit of humanity.",And this is something that we're very excited about.,I showed this slide to Larry Page, who just joined our board. 
 And you know, when you give to a nonprofit,,you might have 50 cents on the dollar.,If you have a matching grant, it's typically two or three to one.,If you put up a prize, you can get literally a 50 to one leverage on your dollars.,And that's huge. And then he turned around and said,,"Well, if you back a prize institute that runs a 10 prize, you get 500 to one.",I said, "Well, that's great.",So, we have actually -- are looking to turn the X PRIZE,into a world-class prize institute.,This is what happens when you put up a prize,,when you announce it and teams start to begin doing trials.,You get publicity increase, and when it's won,,publicity shoots through the roof -- if it's properly managed --,and that's part of the benefits to a sponsor.,Then, when the prize is actually won, after it's moving,,you get societal benefits, you know, new technology, new capability.,And the benefit to the sponsors,is the sum of the publicity and societal benefits over the long term.,That's our value proposition in a prize. 
 If you were going to go and try to create SpaceShipOne,,or any kind of a new technology,,you have to fund that from the beginning,and maintain that funding with an uncertain outcome.,It may or may not happen. But if you put up a prize,,the beautiful thing is, you know, it's a very small maintenance fee,,and you pay on success.,Orteig didn't pay a dime out to the nine teams that went across --,tried to go across the Atlantic,,and we didn't pay a dime until someone won the Ansari X PRIZE.,So, prizes work great.,You know, innovators, the entrepreneurs out there,,you know that when you're going for a goal,,the first thing you have to do is believe,that you can do it yourself.,Then, you've got to, you know, face potential public ridicule,of -- that's a crazy idea, it'll never work.,And then you have to convince others,,so that they can, in fact, help you raise the funds,,and then you've got to deal with the fact that you've got government bureaucracies,and institutions that don't want you to move those things forward,,and you have to deal with failures. What a prize does,,what we've experienced a prize doing,,is literally help to short-circuit or support all of these things,,because a prize credentials the idea that this is a good idea.,Well, it must be a good idea.,Someone's offering 10 million dollars to go and do this thing. 
 And each of these areas was something that we found,the Ansari X PRIZE helped short-circuit these for innovation.,So, as an organization, we put together a prize discovery process,of how to come up with prizes and write the rules,,and we're actually looking at creating prizes,in a number of different categories.,We're looking at attacking energy, environment, nanotechnology --,and I'll talk about those more in a moment.,And the way we're doing that is we're creating prize teams,within the X PRIZE. We have a space prize team.,We're going after an orbital prize. 
 We are looking at a number of energy prizes.,Craig Venter has just joined our board,and we're doing a rapid genome sequencing prize with him,,we'll be announcing later this fall,,about -- imagine being able to sequence anybody's DNA,for under 1,000 dollars, revolutionize medicine.,And clean water, education, medicine and even looking at social entrepreneurship.,So my final slide here is, the most critical tool,for solving humanity's grand challenges -- it isn't technology,,it isn't money, it's only one thing --,it's the committed, passionate human mind. 
 (Applause)My title: "Queerer than we cannsuppose: the strangeness of science.","Queerer than we can suppose" comesnfrom J.B.S. Haldane, the famous biologist,,who said, "Now, my own suspicionnis that the universe is not only queerer,than we suppose, but queerernthan we can suppose.,I suspect that there are more thingsnin heaven and earth,than are dreamed of, or cannbe dreamed of, in any philosophy.",Richard Feynman comparednthe accuracy of quantum theories --,experimental predictions --,to specifying the width of North Americanto within one hair's breadth of accuracy.,This means that quantum theorynhas got to be, in some sense, true.,Yet the assumptionsnthat quantum theory needs to make,in order to deliver thosenpredictions are so mysterious,that even Feynman himselfnwas moved to remark,,"If you think you understandnquantum theory,,you don't understand quantum theory." 
 It's so queer that physicistsnresort to one or another,paradoxical interpretation of it.,David Deutsch, who's talking here,nin "The Fabric of Reality,",embraces the many-worldsninterpretation of quantum theory,,because the worst that youncan say about it,is that it's preposterously wasteful.,It postulates a vast and rapidly growingnnumber of universes existing in parallel,,mutually undetectable,,except through the narrow portholenof quantum mechanical experiments.,And that's Richard Feynman. 
 The biologist Lewis Wolpert believes,that the queerness of modern physics,is just an extreme example.,Science, as opposed to technology,,does violence to common sense.,Every time you drink a glassnof water, he points out,,the odds are that you will imbibenat least one molecule,that passed through the bladdernof Oliver Cromwell.,(Laughter),It's just elementary probability theory. 
 (Laughter) 
 The number of moleculesnper glassful is hugely greater,than the number of glassfuls,nor bladdersful, in the world.,And of course, there's nothing specialnabout Cromwell or bladders --,you have just breathed in a nitrogen atom,that passed through the right lungnof the third iguanodon,to the left of the tall cycad tree. 
 "Queerer than we can suppose.",What is it that makes usncapable of supposing anything,,and does this tell us anythingnabout what we can suppose?,Are there things about the universenthat will be forever beyond our grasp,,but not beyond the graspnof some superior intelligence?,Are there things about the universe,that are, in principle,nungraspable by any mind,,however superior?,The history of science has beennone long series of violent brainstorms,,as successive generationsnhave come to terms with,increasing levels of queernessnin the universe.,We're now so used to the ideanthat the Earth spins,,rather than the Sun moves across the sky,,it's hard for us to realize,what a shattering mental revolutionnthat must have been.,After all, it seems obviousnthat the Earth is large and motionless,,the Sun, small and mobile.,But it's worth recallingnWittgenstein's remark on the subject:,"Tell me," he asked a friend,n"why do people always say,it was natural for man to assumenthat the Sun went 'round the Earth,,rather than that the Earth was rotating?",And his friend replied, "Well, obviously,,because it just looks as thoughnthe Sun is going round the Earth.",Wittgenstein replied, "Well,nwhat would it have looked like,if it had looked as thoughnthe Earth was rotating?" 
 (Laughter) 
 Science has taught us,nagainst all intuition,,that apparently solid things,nlike crystals and rocks,,are really almost entirelyncomposed of empty space.,And the familiar illustrationnis the nucleus of an atom,is a fly in the middlenof a sports stadium,,and the next atomnis in the next sports stadium.,So it would seem the hardest,nsolidest, densest rock,is really almost entirely empty space,,broken only by tiny particlesnso widely spaced they shouldn't count.,Why, then, do rocks look and feelnsolid and hard and impenetrable?,As an evolutionary biologist,nI'd say this: our brains have evolved,to help us survive within the ordersnof magnitude, of size and speed,which our bodies operate at.,We never evolved to navigatenin the world of atoms.,If we had, our brainsnprobably would perceive rocks,as full of empty space.,Rocks feel hard and impenetrable,to our hands, precisely becausenobjects like rocks and hands,cannot penetrate each other.,It's therefore useful,for our brains to construct notionsnlike "solidity" and "impenetrability,",because such notions help usnto navigate our bodies,through the middle-sized worldnin which we have to navigate. 
 Moving to the other end of the scale,,our ancestors never had to navigatenthrough the cosmos,at speeds close to the speed of light.,If they had, our brains would benmuch better at understanding Einstein.,I want to give the name "Middle World"nto the medium-scaled environment,in which we've evolvednthe ability to take act --,nothing to do with "Middle Earth" --,Middle World. 
 (Laughter) 
 We are evolved denizens of Middle World,,and that limits whatnwe are capable of imagining.,We find it intuitively easynto grasp ideas like,,when a rabbit movesnat the sort of medium velocity,at which rabbits and othernMiddle World objects move,,and hits another Middle World objectnlike a rock, it knocks itself out.

 Unaided human intuition,nschooled in Middle World,,finds it hard to believe Galileonwhen he tells us,a heavy object and a light object,nair friction aside,,would hit the ground at the same instant.,And that's because in Middle World,nair friction is always there.,If we'd evolved in a vacuum,,we would expect them to hitnthe ground simultaneously.,If we were bacteria,,constantly buffeted by thermalnmovements of molecules,,it would be different.,But we Middle-Worlders are too bignto notice Brownian motion.,In the same way, our livesnare dominated by gravity,,but are almost obliviousnto the force of surface tension.,A small insect would reversenthese priorities. 
 Steve Grand -- he's the one on the left,,Douglas Adams is on the right.,Steve Grand, in his book,n"Creation: Life and How to Make It,",is positively scathing about ournpreoccupation with matter itself.,We have this tendency to thinknthat only solid, material things,are really things at all.,Waves of electromagnetic fluctuationnin a vacuum seem unreal.,Victorians thought the wavesnhad to be waves in some material medium:,the ether.,But we find real matter comforting,only because we've evolvednto survive in Middle World,,where matter is a useful fiction.,A whirlpool, for Steve Grand,nis a thing with just as much reality,as a rock. 
 In a desert plain in Tanzania,,in the shadow of the volcanonOl Doinyo Lengai,,there's a dune made of volcanic ash.,The beautiful thingnis that it moves bodily.,It's what's technically knownnas a "barchan,",and the entire dune walksnacross the desert in a westerly direction,at a speed of about 17 meters per year.,It retains its crescent shape and movesnin the direction of the horns.,What happens is that the wind blowsnthe sand up the shallow slope,on the other side,,and then, as each sand grain hitsnthe top of the ridge, it cascades down,on the inside of the crescent,,and so the whole horn-shaped dune moves.,Steve Grand points outnthat you and I are, ourselves,,more like a wave than a permanent thing.,He invites us, the reader,,to think of an experiencenfrom your childhood,,something you remember clearly,,something you can see,nfeel, maybe even smell,,as if you were really there.,After all, you really were therenat the time, weren't you?,How else would you remember it?,But here is the bombshell:nYou weren't there.,Not a single atomnthat is in your body today,was there when that event took place.,Matter flows from place to place,and momentarily comes together to be you.,Whatever you are, therefore,,you are not the stuffnof which you are made.,If that doesn't make the hair stand upnon the back of your neck,,read it again until it does,nbecause it is important. 
 So "really" isn't a word that we shouldnuse with simple confidence.,If a neutrino had a brain,,which it evolvednin neutrino-sized ancestors,,it would say that rocks reallyndo consist of empty space.,We have brains that evolvednin medium-sized ancestors,which couldn't walk through rocks.,"Really," for an animal, is whatevernits brain needs it to be,in order to assist its survival.,And because different speciesnlive in different worlds,,there will be a discomfortingnvariety of "reallys.",What we see of the real worldnis not the unvarnished world,,but a model of the world,nregulated and adjusted by sense data,,but constructed so it's usefulnfor dealing with the real world. 
 The nature of the model dependsnon the kind of animal we are.,A flying animal needsna different kind of model,from a walking, climbingnor swimming animal.,A monkey's brain must havensoftware capable of simulating,a three-dimensional worldnof branches and trunks.,A mole's software for constructing modelsnof its world will be customized,for underground use.,A water strider's brainndoesn't need 3D software at all,,since it lives on the surface of the pond,,in an Edwin Abbott flatland. 
 I've speculated that bats may seencolor with their ears.,The world model that a bat needsnin order to navigate,through three dimensions catching insects,must be pretty similar to the worldnmodel that any flying bird --,a day-flying bird like a swallow --nneeds to perform the same kind of tasks.,The fact that the bat usesnechoes in pitch darkness,to input the currentnvariables to its model,,while the swallow usesnlight, is incidental.,Bats, I've even suggested, usenperceived hues, such as red and blue,,as labels, internal labels,nfor some useful aspect of echoes --,perhaps the acoustic texture of surfaces,nfurry or smooth and so on --,in the same way as swallows or indeed,nwe, use those perceived hues --,redness and blueness, etc. --,to label long and shortnwavelengths of light.,There's nothing inherent about rednthat makes it long wavelength. 
 The point is that the nature of the modelnis governed by how it is to be used,,rather than by the sensorynmodality involved.,J.B.S. Haldane himself hadnsomething to say about animals,whose world is dominated by smell.,Dogs can distinguish two very similarnfatty acids, extremely diluted:,caprylic acid and caproic acid.,The only difference, you see,,is that one has an extra pairnof carbon atoms in the chain.,Haldane guesses that a dog would probablynbe able to place the acids,in the order of their molecularnweights by their smells,,just as a man could placena number of piano wires,in the order of their lengthsnby means of their notes.,Now, there's anothernfatty acid, capric acid,,which is just like the other two,,except that it has two more carbon atoms.,A dog that had never metncapric acid would, perhaps,,have no more trouble imagining its smell,than we would have troublenimagining a trumpet, say,,playing one note higher than we've heardna trumpet play before.,Perhaps dogs and rhinos and othernsmell-oriented animals smell in color.,And the argument would be exactlynthe same as for the bats. 
 Middle World -- the rangenof sizes and speeds,which we have evolved to feelnintuitively comfortable with --,is a bit like the narrow rangenof the electromagnetic spectrum,that we see as light of various colors.,We're blind to allnfrequencies outside that,,unless we use instruments to help us.,Middle World is the narrownrange of reality,which we judge to be normal,nas opposed to the queerness,of the very small, the very largenand the very fast.,We could make a similarnscale of improbabilities;,nothing is totally impossible.,Miracles are just eventsnthat are extremely improbable.,A marble statue could wave its hand at us;,the atoms that make upnits crystalline structure,are all vibrating back and forth anyway.,Because there are so many of them,,and because there's nonagreement among them,in their preferred direction of movement,,the marble, as we see itnin Middle World, stays rock steady.,But the atoms in the handncould all just happen to move,the same way at the same time,nand again and again.,In this case, the hand would move,,and we'd see it waving at usnin Middle World.,The odds against it,nof course, are so great,that if you set out writing zerosnat the time of the origin of the universe,,you still would not have writtennenough zeros to this day. 
 Evolution in Middle Worldnhas not equipped us,to handle very improbable events;nwe don't live long enough.,In the vastness of astronomical spacenand geological time,,that which seems impossiblenin Middle World,might turn out to be inevitable.,One way to think about thatnis by counting planets.,We don't know how many planetsnthere are in the universe,,but a good estimate is about 10 to the 20,nor 100 billion billion.,And that gives us a nice way to expressnour estimate of life's improbability.,We could make some sort of landmark pointsnalong a spectrum of improbability,,which might look like the electromagneticnspectrum we just looked at. 
 If life has arisen only once on any --,life could originate once per planet,ncould be extremely common,or it could originate once per star,or once per galaxy or maybe onlynonce in the entire universe,,in which case it would have to be here.,And somewhere up there would be the chance,that a frog would turn into a prince,,and similar magical things like that.,If life has arisen on only one planetnin the entire universe,,that planet has to be our planet,nbecause here we are talking about it.,And that means that if we wantnto avail ourselves of it,,we're allowed to postulate chemical eventsnin the origin of life,which have a probability as lownas one in 100 billion billion.,I don't think we shall havento avail ourselves of that,,because I suspect that lifenis quite common in the universe.,And when I say quite common,nit could still be so rare,that no one island of lifenever encounters another,,which is a sad thought. 
 How shall we interpretn"queerer than we can suppose?",Queerer than can in principle be supposed,,or just queerer than we can suppose,ngiven the limitations,of our brain's evolutionarynapprenticeship in Middle World?,Could we, by training and practice,,emancipate ourselves from Middle World,and achieve some sort of intuitivenas well as mathematical understanding,of the very small and the very large?,I genuinely don't know the answer.,I wonder whether we might help ourselvesnto understand, say, quantum theory,,if we brought up childrennto play computer games,beginning in early childhood,,which had a make-believe world of ballsngoing through two slits on a screen,,a world in which the strange goings-onnof quantum mechanics were enlarged,by the computer's make-believe,,so that they became familiarnon the Middle-World scale of the stream.,And similarly, a relativisticncomputer game,,in which objects on the screen manifestnthe Lorentz contraction, and so on,,to try to get ourselves -- to get childrenninto the way of thinking about it. 
 I want to end by applyingnthe idea of Middle World,to our perceptions of each other.,Most scientists today subscribento a mechanistic view of the mind:,we're the way we are because our brainsnare wired up as they are,,our hormones are the way they are.,We'd be different, our charactersnwould be different,,if our neuro-anatomy and ournphysiological chemistry were different.,But we scientists are inconsistent.,If we were consistent,,our response to a misbehavingnperson, like a child-murderer,,should be something like:,this unit has a faulty component;nit needs repairing.,That's not what we say.,What we say -- and I includenthe most austerely mechanistic among us,,which is probably me --,what we say is, "Vile monster,nprison is too good for you.",Or worse, we seek revenge,nin all probability thereby triggering,the next phase in an escalatingncycle of counter-revenge,,which we see, of course,nall over the world today.,In short, when we'renthinking like academics,,we regard people as elaboratenand complicated machines,,like computers or cars.,But when we revert to being human,,we behave more like Basil Fawlty,nwho, we remember,,thrashed his car to teach it a lesson,,when it wouldn't start on "Gourmet Night." 
 (Laughter) 
 The reason we personify thingsnlike cars and computers,is that just as monkeys livenin an arboreal world,and moles live in an underground world,and water striders live in a surfacentension-dominated flatland,,we live in a social world.,We swim through a sea of people --,a social version of Middle World.,We are evolved to second-guessnthe behavior of others,by becoming brilliant,nintuitive psychologists.,Treating people as machines,may be scientificallynand philosophically accurate,,but it's a cumbersome waste of time,if you want to guess what this personnis going to do next.,The economically useful waynto model a person,is to treat him as a purposeful,ngoal-seeking agent,with pleasures and pains,ndesires and intentions,,guilt, blame-worthiness.,Personification and the imputingnof intentional purpose,is such a brilliantly successfulnway to model humans,,it's hardly surprisingnthe same modeling software,often seizes control when we'rentrying to think about entities,for which it's not appropriate,nlike Basil Fawlty with his car,or like millions of deluded people,nwith the universe as a whole. 
 (Laughter) 
 If the universe is queerernthan we can suppose,,is it just becausenwe've been naturally selected,to suppose only what we needed to suppose,in order to survivenin the Pleistocene of Africa?,Or are our brains so versatilenand expandable that we can train ourselves,to break out of the box of our evolution?,Or finally, are there some thingsnin the universe so queer,that no philosophy of beings,nhowever godlike, could dream them?
