 And the question is,nis this good news, or bad news?,And the answer is, "yes." 
 (Laughter) 
 We all know what's good about it,,so I'm going to talknabout what's bad about it.,All of this choice has two effects,,two negative effects on people.,One effect, paradoxically,,is that it produces paralysis,nrather than liberation.,With so many options to choose from,,people find it very difficultnto choose at all.,I'll give you one veryndramatic example of this:,a study that was done of investmentsnin voluntary retirement plans.,A colleague of mine got accessnto investment records from Vanguard,,the gigantic mutual-fund company,of about a million employeesnand about 2,000 different workplaces.,And what she found,is that for every 10 mutual fundsnthe employer offered,,rate of participationnwent down two percent.,You offer 50 funds -- 10 percentnfewer employees participate,than if you only offer five.,Why?,Because with 50 funds to choose from,,it's so damn hard to decidenwhich fund to choose,,that you'll just put it offnuntil tomorrow.,And then tomorrow,,and tomorrow, and tomorrow,,and of course tomorrow never comes.,Understand that not only does this mean,that people are going to havento eat dog food when they retire,because they don't havenenough money put away,,it also means that makingnthe decision is so hard,that they pass up significantnmatching money from the employer.,By not participating, they are passing upnas much as 5,000 dollars a year,from the employer,,who would happilynmatch their contribution. 
 So paralysis is a consequencenof having too many choices.,And I think it makesnthe world look like this. 
 [And lastly, for all eternity,nFrench, bleu cheese, or ranch?] 
 (Laughter) 
 You really want to get the decisionnright if it's for all eternity, right?,You don't want to pick the wrongnmutual fund, or the wrong salad dressing.,So that's one effect.,The second effect,is that even if we manage to overcomenthe paralysis and make a choice,,we end up less satisfiednwith the result of the choice,than we would be if we hadnfewer options to choose from.,And there are several reasons for this.,One of them,is that with a lot of differentnsalad dressings to choose from,,if you buy one, and it's not perfect --nand what salad dressing is? --,it's easy to imaginenyou could have made a different choice,that would have been better.,And what happens,is this imagined alternative induces younto regret the decision you made,,and this regret subtractsnfrom the satisfaction,you get out of the decision you made,,even if it was a good decision.,The more options there are,nthe easier it is to regret anything at all,that is disappointingnabout the option that you chose. 
 Second, what economistsncall "opportunity costs.",Dan Gilbert made a big point this morning,of talking about how much the waynin which we value things,depends on what we compare them to.,Well, when there are lotsnof alternatives to consider,,it is easy to imaginenthe attractive features,of alternatives that you reject,that make you less satisfiednwith the alternative that you've chosen.,Here's an example. 
 [I can't stop thinking about those othernavailable parking spaces on W 85th street] 
 Sorry if you're not New Yorkers.,Here's what you'rensupposed to be thinking.,Here's this couple on the Hamptons.,Very expensive real estate.,Gorgeous beach. Beautiful day.nThey have it all to themselves.,What could be better?,"Well, damn it," this guy is thinking,,"It's August. Everybodynin my Manhattan neighborhood is away.,I could be parkingnright in front of my building.",And he spends two weeks nagged by the idea,that he is missing the opportunity,,day after day, to havena great parking space.,Opportunity costs,subtract from the satisfactionnwe get out of what we choose,,even when what we choose is terrific.,And the more optionsnthere are to consider,,the more attractivenfeatures of these options,are going to be reflectednby us as opportunity costs.

 Now this cartoon makes a lot of points.,It makes points about livingnin the moment as well,,and probably about doing things slowly.,But one point it makes,is that whenevernyou're choosing one thing,,you're choosing not to do other things,that may have lots of attractive features,,and it's going to makenwhat you're doing less attractive. 
 Third: escalation of expectations.,This hit me when I wentnto replace my jeans.,I wear jeans almost all the time.,There was a timenwhen jeans came in one flavor,,and you bought them,nand they fit like crap,,they were incredibly uncomfortable,,if you wore themnand washed them enough times,,they started to feel OK.,I went to replace my jeans after yearsnof wearing these old ones,,and I said, "I wantna pair of jeans.  (Laughter) 
 He had no idea what that was, 
 (Laughter) 
 so I spent an hour trying onnall these damn jeans,,and I walked out of the store -- truth! --,with the best-fitting jeansnI had ever had.,I did better. 
 All this choice madenit possible for me to do better.,But --,I felt worse.,Why? I wrote a whole booknto try to explain this to myself.,The reason -- 
 (Laughter) 
 The reason I felt worse is that,,with all of these options available,,my expectations about how goodna pair of jeans should be went up.,I had very low, no particular expectationsnwhen they only came in one flavor.,When they came in 100 flavors, damn it,none of them should've been perfect.,And what I got was good,nbut it wasn't perfect.,And so I compared what I gotnto what I expected,,and what I got was disappointingnin comparison to what I expected.,Adding options to people's lives,can't help but increasenthe expectations people have,about how good those options will be.,And what that's going to producenis less satisfaction with results,,even when they're good results.,Nobody in the worldnof marketing knows this.

 Because if they did, you wouldn't all knownwhat this was about.,The truth is more like this. 
 [Everything was better backnwhen everything was worse] 
 The reason that everything was betternback when everything was worse,is that when everything was worse,,it was actually possible for people,to have experiencesnthat were a pleasant surprise.,Nowadays, the world we live in --nwe affluent, industrialized citizens,,with perfection the expectation --,the best you can ever hope for,is that stuff is as goodnas you expect it to be.,You will never be pleasantly surprised,because your expectations,nmy expectations,,have gone through the roof.,The secret to happiness --nthis is what you all came for --,the secret to happiness,is low expectations.

 I want to say --,just a little autobiographical moment --,that I actually am married to a wife,,and she's really quite wonderful.,I couldn't have done better.,I didn't settle.,But settling isn'tnalways such a bad thing. 
 Finally --,One consequence of buyingna bad-fitting pair of jeans,when there is only one kind to buy,is that when you are dissatisfied,nand you ask why,,who's responsible,,the answer is clear:nthe world is responsible.,What could you do?,When there are hundredsnof different styles of jeans available,,and you buy one that is disappointing,,and you ask why, who's responsible?,It is equally clear that the answernto the question is "you.",You could have done better.,With a hundred different kindsnof jeans on display,,there is no excuse for failure.,And so when people make decisions,,and even though the resultsnof the decisions are good,,they feel disappointed about them;,they blame themselves. 
 Clinical depression has exploded,in the industrial worldnin the last generation.,I believe a significant -- not the only,nbut a significant -- contributor,to this explosion of depression,nand also suicide,,is that people have experiencesnthat are disappointing,because their standards are so high,,and then when they have to explainnthese experiences to themselves,,they think they're at fault.,And so the net result is that we donbetter in general, objectively,,and we feel worse.,So let me remind you.,This is the official dogma,nthe one that we all take to be true,,and it's all false.,It is not true.,There's no question that some choicenis better than none,,but it doesn't follow from that,that more choicenis better than some choice.,There's some magical amount.nI don't know what it is.,I'm pretty confident that we havenlong since passed the point,where options improve our welfare. 
 Now, as a policy matter --nI'm almost done --,as a policy matter,nthe thing to think about is this:,what enables all of this choice,in industrial societiesnis material affluence.,There are lots of places in the world,,and we have heard about several of them,,where their problemnis not that they have too much choice.,Their problemnis that they have too little.,So the stuff I'm talking aboutnis the peculiar problem,of modern, affluent, Western societies.,And what is so frustratingnand infuriating is this:,Steve Levitt talked to you yesterday,about how these expensivenand difficult-to-install child seats,don't help.,It's a waste of money.,What I'm telling you,is that these expensive,ncomplicated choices --,it's not simply that they don't help.,They actually hurt.,They actually make us worse off. 
 If some of what enablesnpeople in our societies,to make all of the choices we make,were shifted to societiesnin which people have too few options,,not only would thosenpeople's lives be improved,,but ours would be improved also,,which is what economists callna "Pareto-improving move.",Income redistribution will makeneveryone better off --,not just poor people --,because of how all this excessnchoice plagues us.,So to conclude.,[You can be anythingnyou want to be -- no limits],You're supposed to read this cartoon,nand, being a sophisticated person, say,,"Ah! What does this fish know?,You know, nothing is possiblenin this fishbowl.",Impoverished imagination,na myopic view of the world --,and that's the way I read it at first.,The more I thought about it, however,,the more I came to the viewnthat this fish knows something.,Because the truth of the matter,is that if you shatter the fishbowlnso that everything is possible,,you don't have freedom.,You have paralysis.,If you shatter this fishbowlnso that everything is possible,,you decrease satisfaction.,You increase paralysis,nand you decrease satisfaction. 
 Everybody needs a fishbowl.,This one is almostncertainly too limited --,perhaps even for the fish,ncertainly for us.,But the absence of some metaphoricalnfishbowl is a recipe for misery,,and, I suspect, disaster.
